See the FDA's letter:

F.D.A. Orders Genetic Testing Firm to Stop Selling DNA Analysis Service
By ANDREW POLLACK
Published: November 25, 2013
http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/26/business/fda-demands-a-halt-to-a-dna-t...
perfectly and clearly stated and better stated than the article.

You're simply re-stating what the article says, are you not? "Companies choose which SNPs to read. By comparing the technical reports provided with my results, I found that my tests sometimes relied on different SNPs to assess the same condition, like coronary heart disease. Each test studied four to 15 markers, with almost zero overlap, though two tests reached similar conclusions about my odds."

Hi all, I am a geneticist. What the woman writing this article doesn't understand is that even if the three companies found the exact same DNA sequences (which is impossible due to normal machine error), each of the companies most likely used different calculations based on different studies to determine her disease risks, hence the different results. That doesn't mean that there is some magic number which is the correct one, it is based on what those studies found (which will absolutely change once more studies come out).
She also states that 23andme got in trouble with the FDA about not being accurate, which is incorrect. The FDA cited them for not being clear to the lay public about what the results mean. Personally, I think that how 23andme explain the results are clear to understand. Does my explanation make sense?
I don't know about the other companies, but 23andme does use numbers like you have a  '7 out of 100' chance, where the average person has a '3 out of a 100' chance.

23andme shows you which studies were used in calculating your disease risks, so people can read them for themselves. All of the papers used for my calculations were paid for by the U.S. or foreign governments to Universities and medical institutions, and not even one was paid for by corporations or drug companies. Therefore I feel more confident in the results. Regardless, a lot of research still needs to be done if you take into account the sheer complexity of the human genome, its a complicated natural system just like any other in physics, chemistry, biology, etc.

I agree that the news does report results stronger than they actually are, as well as top journals like Science. Luckily 23andme gives you a confidence estimate based on how many papers are supporting your risk estimate, and the quality of those studies.

This is not meant as a criticism, merely as a question to ponder.  Why is it that you think one needs to remain anonymous to facilitate candor? There are many on these boards who, ostensibly, use their own names and it does not appear to interfere with their candor.  What is it that you would say under a nom de plume that you would be embarrassed to acknowledge under your given name?  And, if you would not admit to an opinion amongst your circle of acquaintances what value does that opinion hold for you?

Open-mindedness and rashness can both be promoted by social media.

Open-mindedness is enhanced when one is exposed to opinions that counter one's own, something that can be facilitated by the social media.

At the same time, anonymity, while enhancing candor, reduces social inhibitions and can lead to rashness and disrespect. I comment under a nom de plume in the Times to facilitate candor; in 2014 I will redouble my efforts to remain civil.

Richard, miners capture the transaction fees.  Even after all 21 million coins are minted, there will still be incentive for miners to continue their operations. You would think it was a terrible year if you were among the long term unemployed.
I am. But I have savings, friends, family, a place to live. My kids are grown and employed. I don't need much. You'd be amazed how frugally you can live in the UK.

A couple of thoughts:
1) it really hasn't been a bad year for me or most people I know, both in the States or in the UK. Words like "terrible year" are spin. It really has been a terrible year in places like Syria and Central Africa. Can we please get a realistic sense of proportion here?

2) Inequality, per se, is not the problem. Incomes have been rising for the poorest all around the world. Obviously income has been rising more for those at the top than for those on hourly wages or salaries, largely because those at the top have other sources of income.

3) The big problem is world-wide underemployment. Young people around the world, in China, Russia, Europe, the Muslim world, India, Africa, S. America, and the USA, simply are not getting work and compensation commensurate with their education and their abilities. This is the big problem, and it may be structural, and it may be how things are going to be for quite a while.

I was one of those self-employed and uninsured, and I have just gotten my coverage through the Market Place. I look forward to having my first routine physical exam comes next year since I was last insured 12 years ago. So I am definitely one of the "winner" of this new law.

I am however not as optimistic as Krugman. I wonder if he had actually looked at the different policies at different levels. I wonder if there has been comparisons of similar plans from before ACA and their prices. One of the premise of an exchange is that competition will drive down prices. In the example of state of Florida, there are only two companies, Cigna and BCBS offering plans. The premiums of even the cheapest plans, from anecdotal comparisons of some friends' pre or non-ACA plans, are much higher with much higher deductible.

I suspect the insurers are taking advantage of the availability of federal subsidy to offset the high premium and getting away with offering plans with high premium and high deductible.

Now that I have seen the subsidy I myself is qualified and heard the stories of others, though not a Republican, I do wonder if such subsidy for such high prices health plans is affordable and sustainable long term? Is this not a transfer of wealth to one sector of the big corporations?

Prof. Reinhardt,

All hell would break loose? We read stories of people waiting hours to get free care at special events organized for people without health insurance, and more, and has all hell broken loose? Congress has no problem with giving people different levels of care at all.

No, the pretense that Congress engages in is that it cherishes life. It does that by restricting abortion and championing the causes of people like Terry Schiavo. The prospect of taking her off life support made all hell break loose in Congress.

But that wasn't the question that was asked. The question was what is the basis for the supposed obligation to purchase healthcare for America's lower income families.

And to that, I think the right answers might include:
Human decency and a sense of fairness
Desire to ease human suffering.
Medical ethics and a calling to heal the sick

I find the reference to congress or the media to be completely besides the point.
